_decoded_content.title: Give tap and target developers a "Get it on Meltano" badge
_decoded_content.description:
https://meltano.slack.com/archives/C01PKLU5D1R/p1647416381125879?thread_ts=1647388209.417079&cid=C01PKLU5D1R

From @emcp:

> I wonder aloud if there is also a “One Click Deploy” or Badge I can add in future to my tap.. like “Get it on MeltanoHub”

In theory, we could add create a default (probably commented-out) badge to the cookiecutter readmes. The developer would just need to update the link to it goes to the correct page on hub.meltano.com.

Something like this from shields.io could work:

```
[![](https://img.shields.io/badge/-Get%20it%20on%20Meltano-purple)](https://hub.meltano.com/taps/adwords#usage-with-meltano)
```

Renders as:

[![](https://img.shields.io/badge/-Get%20it%20on%20Meltano-purple)](https://hub.meltano.com/taps/adwords#usage-with-meltano)

_decoded_content.title: Should Hub have a relational database backend
_decoded_content.description:
This keeps coming up so I want to address it. Sounds we're mostly expecting we'll eventually add an RDMS but for me, this has always been an architectural antipattern. (Admittedly I'm not a front end dev.)

At Amazon, traditional RDMS's were expressly forbidden for any production workloads that needed to scale, so I'm admittedly pre-biased against RDBM's and OLTP use cases for the Hub.

Would be helpful to understand what requirements we feel like would be benefited from an RDMS. 

If we do have use cases that will require RDMS backend, I'd like to understand those better so I can update my own expectations and so we can start designing the long-term solution that we need.

_decoded_content.title: Link to MeltanoLabs Singer Most Wanted
_decoded_content.description:
If someone comes to find a tap/target but it doesnt exist we tell them to add it to MeltanoHub. We're getting to a point where most existing in the wild are on MeltanoHub unless theyve just recently been developed. I think its fair to start assuming that the tap doesnt exist and they should try putting in a request to add the connector in MeltanoLabs.

It will help in consistently sourcing the most important connectors so its clear during a tap-a-thon what the most valuable connectors are.

_decoded_content.title: Improve details on all plugins pages
_decoded_content.description: Based on discussions and learnings in #1+ we need to overhaul the look and feel of plugin detail pages.

_decoded_content.title: Revamped Hub Search
_decoded_content.description:
Meltano Hub needs to be revamped with the following feature updates:

- A search bar available when you first hit the Meltano Hub site.
- The search bar looks for exact word searches but also looks for keywords and descriptions (e.g. a search for Excel would turn up tap-spreadsheets-anywhere
- A details grid would be returned when searching that would allow for better readability of results as well as allow for filtering (preferably with a toggle interface).

_decoded_content.title: Support adding all plugins, including utilities, to Meltano through the hub
_decoded_content.description:
It would be awesome if like taps and targets you could submit utility plug-ins, (and other plug-ins), into Meltano through the hub.

For example: I've been working on a [notebook utility](https://github.com/Matatika/notebook) that I use as a custom plug-in in Meltano. I think adding it to Meltano would benefit others, and it being on the hub and making it easy to find/read about would make it even better.

_decoded_content.title: Add Sonarcloud badges
_decoded_content.description:
Related to #186.

Per https://gitlab.com/meltano/hub/-/issues/186#note_818305023 we could add the sonarcloud pages.

FYI @pnadolny13 @edgarrmondragon

_decoded_content.title: More granular set of capabilities around catalog input
_decoded_content.description:
SDK-based taps support the following catalog overrides and metadata:

- Select streams
- Set other stream and property metadata `replication-method`, `replication-key`, `is-replication-key`, etc.
- Select stream properties
- Override stream schema

However, other taps out there don't support all of the above and usually they only support the first two at best.

Ideally, all taps should support rich metadata and schema overrides and the SDK will help us get there, but in the meantime I propose a more granular set of documented capabilities around the catalog:

- `catalog:select-streams`
- `catalog:select-properties`
- `catalog:metadata-streams`
- `catalog:metadata-properties`
- `catalog:schema-override`

Another question is whether we should make Meltano itself aware of these capabilities and warn users when they're using `schema` with a tap that doesn't support schema overrides, for example.

_decoded_content.title: Optional FAQ section for plugins
_decoded_content.description:
It would be interesting if as part of auto-generated page for each plugin, we had zero or more FAQ entries that are also populated from YAML.

This occurred to me as a follow-on from this Slack thread https://meltano.slack.com/archives/CMN8HELB0/p1638869197146700?thread_ts=1638869197.146700&cid=CMN8HELB0 where a user was able to solve their connection problem to Atlas following a recommendation given in a GitHub issue: https://github.com/singer-io/tap-mongodb/issues/42#issuecomment-866379009.

It's not exactly a bug in the tap itself but rather how to make it work with a hosted provider of the source. There may be similar recommendations for Postgres on RDS, etc.

_decoded_content.title: Jobs to be done with MeltanoHub
_decoded_content.description:
Goal with this is to document some of the main jobs to be done by MeltanoHub to help guide design and architecture decisions. Original launch [blog post](https://meltano.com/blog/meltanohub-for-singer-launches-with-over-200-taps-and-targets/).

Meltano:
* discover available plugins for Meltano the DataOps OS
* find and use [reference docus](https://documentation.divio.com/) for using these plugins

Singer:
* discover available taps and targets 
* understand the overall quality (commits, usage, maintenance status, updates) of any given connector
* understand the overall level of support of any given connector
* understand how to use a tap in conjunction with a target (and vice versa) alone and with Meltano
* find resources on how to build a new connector
* Learn about the Singer specification
* programmatically access the available taps and targets as well as the settings for particular connectors


General:
* enable maintainers to present themselves well, showcase the plugins they maintain, potentially be reached by users
* enable users to contribute new plugins to the Hub
* enable users to correct / improve plugin information

_decoded_content.title: Move Maintenance Status Descriptions to MeltanoHub
_decoded_content.description: I think we should move these [maintenance statuses](https://github.com/MeltanoLabs/Meta#maintenance-statuses) from MeltanoLabs to MeltanoHub to define what the labels mean in that context. We should split some of the status attributes out of the descriptions to make them more appropriate for each environment. MeltanoLabs can link to the MeltanoHub descriptions and append a few extra attributes ("All maintenance status attributes from MeltanoLabs, plus X other attributes"). We expect MeltanoLabs to have a higher level of quality for example CI pipelines which arent a requirement in MeltanoHub.

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description:
As a start, I think it would be good to prioritize based on:
- urgency of getting feedback
- relative implementation difficulty
- symbiotic relationships between issues

_decoded_content.title: Consider webhook-based testing framework
_decoded_content.description:
Just brainstorming here... rather than require a full config (with auth!) for testing taps, what if we established a pattern of webhook-based testing?

Specifically, the developer could take a commit ref as input param and (optionally) could require a secret token that could be used to authenticate the caller as Meltano.

If we (Meltano) publish a public key, we could then use our own private key to certify ourselves as caller.

One option for execution would be as a manual CI, which only Meltano staff or certified tap maintainers would be allowed to execute. In practice, this might run a Lambda-based execution of the tap using `--test` or wrapped with `meltano config extractor <tapname> test`.

This differs from existing approaches because credentials are not stored in the repo's CI system, only the ability to call the webhook.

cc @pandemicsyn, @edgarrmondragon, @pnadolny13

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description:

_decoded_content.title: Example meltano.yml generated for all taps/targets
_decoded_content.description:
Guessing this isn't a new idea, but I didn't see it listed in the issues list. 

Looking at https://hub.meltano.com/taps/clickup and thought why do people need to create their own custom extractor meltano configuration.

On top of the data listed there, we could also generate a meltano.yml file

```yml
plugins:
  extractors:
  - name: tap-clickup
    namespace: tap_clickup
    pip_url: tap-clickup
    capabilities:
    - state
    - catalog
    - discover
    settings:
    select:
    - '*.*'
    config:
      start_date: 'todo'
      api_token: 'todo'
```

I know that's what the `discovery.yml` piece is for, but it seems like we could get pretty close here?

_decoded_content.title: CI job to add settings if tap supports `--about`
_decoded_content.description:
I think we should write a script to add or update settings documentation from `--about --format=json` in two forms:

1. As a one-time job on a loop.
2. As an on-demand (aka "manual") CI job taking the tap name and variant name as inputs.
3. Failures to install or run would be logged for follow-up.

Other notes:

- Ideally, to save execution time, we'd filter this to just those taps which are marked as built with the SDK.
- If running locally, this should probably be run inside a docker container, for easy cleanup afterwards.
- pipx has a pipx run command which bootstraps the install and runs any CLI command. So in theory, this should work: `pipx run {pip_url} --about --format=json > {tap_name}--{variant_name}.about.json`
- We'll probably want to smartly merge the output, adding settings if missing but not overriding non-null text descriptions with null ones.

_decoded_content.title: Opinionated evaluation framework for tap and target capabilites (Gold/Silver/Bronze)
_decoded_content.description:
The Singer ecosystem has a LOT of great taps - and over time, clear best practices and must-have features have slowly emerged. This issue will attempt to enumerate what would make a "Bronze", "Silver", or "Gold" level of quality for a given tap or target.

1. 🥉 "Bronze"-level capabilities - Entry-level stability and interoperability
    - :small_blue_diamond: `Catalog` (newer) or `Properties` (legacy)
    - :small_blue_diamond: `Discovery` to print catalog json
2. 🥈 "Silver"-level capabilities - Good user experience across the board, fits most use cases
    - :small_blue_diamond: `Catalog` _(not `Properties`, which is legacy)_
    - :small_blue_diamond: `State` and incremental replication
    - :small_blue_diamond: `Selection` of streams and properties via catalog metadata
    - ▪️`ACTIVATE` message type tolerance (targets only, receiving ACTIVATE doesn't cause failure)
3. 🏆 "Gold"-level capabilities - "just works" for every foreseeable use case
    - `Log-Based Replication` (if applicable)
    - `Target Schema Mapping` - (targets only)
    - :small_blue_diamond: `Record flattening` - (targets only, columnar only)
    - ▪️`ACTIVATE` message type support (taps and targets)
    - `Complex data types` - (for targets only, fallback to string rather than failing if data type is unknown)
4. :gift: "Bonus" capabilities - additional to the above. Not a level, just a list of additional features.
    - :small_blue_diamond:`Stream Maps` 
    - :small_blue_diamond: `BATCH` message type
    - :small_blue_diamond: `--about` to print capabilities and config expectations
    - ▪️ `--demo` to send dummy data and config-less discovery (Upcoming)

:small_blue_diamond: = Features that come out-of-box with the SDK (or will soon)
▪️ = Features assisted by the SDK but still requiring some developer effort

Please post in the comments if you'd like to propose additional items in this taxonomy - or to move something around.

_decoded_content.title: Enable users to submit new connectors via the UI
_decoded_content.description: Following from https://gitlab.com/meltano/hub/-/issues/5 there should be a way to submit new connectors via the UI even if it's making an MR on the backend.

_decoded_content.title: Document how we're deploying Meltano for the hub
_decoded_content.description:
With https://gitlab.com/meltano/hub/-/issues/15 we're truly dogfooding Meltano (https://gitlab.com/meltano/meta/-/issues/4). This is a great opportunity to create some relevant content around this effort.

- [ ] Blog Post on how we're using Meltano to build the Hub
- [ ] Documentation update in several areas:
  - [ ] Cross-link in https://meltano.com/docs/production.html
  - [ ] We should have a section on the Hub on how we're building the hub "Architecture" 
  - [ ] Create a "Production Deployments in the Wild" section or something like that within the Meltano documentation. We can link ours and the GitLab data team's.

_decoded_content.title: Consider how to document and manage OSS vs proprietary taps
_decoded_content.description:
It came up in discussion about how people might want to use the hub for proprietary and unlisted use cases. The spec and the base design of the SingerHub should be built thinking about this at the start. 

I'd estimate the following % for each type:

| Code-type | Listed | Unlisted |
| ------ | ------ | ---- |
| OSS | 90% | <1% |
| Proprietary | 5% | <5% | 

We're going to focus most of our effort on the open source community, but will build will related use cases in mind.

_decoded_content.title: Adding Testing/Validation status badges on plugin pages
_decoded_content.description: Following from https://gitlab.com/meltano/meltano/-/issues/2612#note_518395941, it would be good to indicate to users the validity of a given tap or target in a programmatic way. We've started to do this manually by adding Repository, Maintainer, and Maintenance Status on plugin pages (see https://meltano.com/plugins/extractors/chargebee.html) but we should be able to programmatically pull from repositories.

_decoded_content.title: Central validation infrastructure for tap/target integration testing
_decoded_content.description:
Following from https://gitlab.com/meltano/meltano/-/issues/2612#note_518395941 it would be useful to have some centralized redundant validation that a tap/target does what it say it can do.

@DouweM mentioned that realistically we may not be able to do more than validating `<executable> --help` works, but even having basic documentation checks would be useful to better encourage useability across the ecosystem.
